text: The proverbs of David’s son Solomon, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These proverbs are for gaining wisdom and discipline;
    for understanding words of insight;
speaker: Narrator

text:
for acquiring the discipline that produces wise behavior,
    righteousness, justice, and upright living;
speaker: Narrator

text:
for giving prudence to the naïve,
    and knowledge and discretion to the young.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the wise listen and increase their learning;
    let the person of understanding receive guidance
speaker: Narrator

text:
in understanding proverbs, clever sayings,
    words of the wise, and their riddles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge,
    but fools despise wisdom and discipline.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, listen to your father’s instruction,
    and do not let go of your mother’s teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will be a graceful wreath for your head
    and a chain for your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, if sinners entice you,
    do not consent.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Let’s swallow them alive like Sheol,
    and whole like those who go down into the Pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We’ll find all kinds of valuable wealth,
    and we’ll fill our houses with spoil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Throw your lot in with us,
    and all of us will have one purse.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, do not go along with them,
    and keep your feet away from their paths!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they run toward evil;
    these enticers shed blood without hesitation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, it is useless to spread a net in full view of all the birds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but these people lie in wait for their own blood.
        They ambush only themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such is the way of all those who seek illicit gain—
    it takes away the lives of those who possess it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom cries out in the street;
    she raises her voice in the public squares.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She calls out at the busiest part of the noisy streets,
    and at the entrance to the gates of the city she utters her words:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You naïve ones, how long will you love naiveté?
    And how long will scoffers delight in scoffing
        or fools hate knowledge?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Return to my correction!
    Look, I will pour out my spirit on you,
        and I will make my words known to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Because I called out to you and you refused to respond—
    I appealed, but no one paid attention—
speaker: Narrator

text:
because you neglected all my advice
    and did not want my correction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will laugh at your calamity.
    I will mock when what you fear comes,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when what you dread comes like a storm,
    and your calamity comes on like a whirlwind,
        when distress and anguish come upon you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then they will call out to me,
    but I will not answer;
they will seek me diligently,
    but they will not find me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Because they hated knowledge
    and did not choose the fear of the Lord;
speaker: Narrator

text:
they did not want my advice,
    and they rejected all my correction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will eat the fruit of their way,
    and they will be filled with their own devices.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, the waywardness of the naïve will kill them,
    and the complacency of fools will destroy them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But the person who listens to me will live safely
    and will be secure from the fear of evil.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, if you accept my words,
and treasure my instructions—
speaker: Narrator

text:
making your ear attentive to wisdom,
    and turning your heart to understanding—
speaker: Narrator

text:
if, indeed, you call out for insight
    and raise your voice for understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if you seek it like silver
    and search for it like hidden treasure,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then you will understand the fear of the Lord
    and learn to know God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord gives wisdom,
    and from his mouth come knowledge and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He stores up sound wisdom for the upright
    and is a shield to those who walk in integrity—
speaker: Narrator

text:
guarding the paths of the just
    and protecting the way of his faithful ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will understand what is right, just,
    and upright—every good path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For wisdom will enter your heart,
    and knowledge will be pleasant to your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Discretion will protect you;
    understanding will watch over you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
delivering you from the way of evil,
    from men who speak perverse things,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and from those who abandon the right path
    to travel along the ways of darkness;
speaker: Narrator

text:
who delight in doing evil,
    and rejoice in the perverseness of evil;
speaker: Narrator

text:
whose paths are crooked
    and who are devious in their ways,
speaker: Narrator

text:
delivering you from the adulteress,
    from the immoral woman with her seductive words,
speaker: Narrator

text:
someone who abandoned the companion of her youth
        and forgot the covenant of her God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For her house leads down to death,
    and her paths down to the realm of the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
None who go to her return,
nor do they reach the paths of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is how you will walk in the way of good men
    and will keep to the paths of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the upright will live in the land,
    and people of integrity will remain in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the wicked will be cut off from the land,
    and the treacherous will be uprooted from it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, don’t forget my instruction,
and keep my commandments carefully in mind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they will add length to your days, years to your life,
    and abundant peace to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not let gracious love and truth leave you.
    Bind them around your neck,
        write them on the tablet of your heart,
speaker: Narrator

text: and find favor and a good reputation with God and men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trust in the Lord with all your heart,
    and do not depend on your own understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In all your ways acknowledge him,
    and he will make your paths straight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be wise in your own opinion.
    Fear the Lord and turn away from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This will bring healing to your body,
    and refreshment to your bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honor the Lord with your wealth
    and with the first of all your produce,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so your barns will be filled with abundance,
    and your vats will burst open with new wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, do not reject the Lord’s discipline,
    and do not despise his correction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because the Lord corrects the person he loves,
    just as a father corrects the son he delights in.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How joyful is the man who finds wisdom,
    and the man who gains understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because her profit is better than the profit of silver,
    and her yield than fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is more precious than rubies,
    and nothing you desire compares with her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Long life is in her right hand,
    and in her left are riches and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her ways are pleasant ways,
    and all her paths are peaceful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is a tree of life for those who embrace her,
    and whoever clutches her tightly will be joyful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By wisdom the Lord laid the earth’s foundations,
    and by understanding he set the heavens in place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By his knowledge the depths broke open,
    and the clouds drip with dew.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, do not let wisdom leave your sight.
    Carefully observe sound judgment and discernment,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and they will be life to you
    and a graceful ornament for your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will travel safely on your way,
    and your foot will not stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you sit down, you will not be afraid;
    when you lie down, your sleep will be pleasant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be afraid of sudden disaster,
    or the devastation that comes to the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, the Lord will be your confidence,
    and he will keep your foot from being caught.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due,
    when it is in your power to act.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not say to your neighbor,
    “Go, and come back.
        I will pay you tomorrow,”
when you have cash with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not plan to harm your neighbor,
    when he is living peacefully beside you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not bring a lawsuit against a person for no reason,
    when he has done you no harm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not envy a violent man,
    and do not emulate his lifestyle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, a perverse man is utterly disgusting to the Lord,
    but he takes the upright into his confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord’s curse is on the house of the wicked,
    but he blesses the dwelling of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though God scoffs at scoffers,
    he gives grace to the humble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise will inherit honor,
    but he holds fools up for ridicule.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, children, to your father’s instruction,
and pay attention in order to gain understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I give you sound teaching,
so do not abandon my instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I was a son to my father,
    not yet strong and an only son to my mother,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Get wisdom! Get understanding!
    Do not forget or turn aside from the words of my mouth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not abandon her, and she will protect you.
    Love her, and she will watch over you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is of utmost importance, therefore get wisdom,
    and with all your effort work to acquire understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Prize her and she will exalt you.
    Indeed, if you embrace her, she will honor you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She will place on your head a graceful garland;
    she will present to you a crown of beauty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, my son: accept my words,
    and you’ll live a long, long time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have directed you in the way of wisdom,
    and I have led you along straight paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you walk, your step will not be hindered,
    and when you run, you will not stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hold on to instruction, do not let it go!
    Guard wisdom, because she is your life!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not enter the path of the wicked,
    or go along the way of evil men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Avoid it! Don’t travel on it!
    Turn away from it, and pass on by.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they cannot sleep unless they are doing evil,
    and they are robbed of their sleep unless they cause someone to stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they eat the bread of wickedness,
    and they drink the wine of violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The path of the righteous is like the light of dawn
    that grows brighter until the full light of day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the way of the wicked is like deep darkness,
    and they do not know what they are stumbling over.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, pay attention to my words,
    and listen closely to what I say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not let them out of your sight;
    keep them within your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they are life to those who find them,
    and healing to their whole body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Above everything else guard your heart,
    because from it flow the springs of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never talk deceptively
    and don’t keep company with people whose speech is corrupt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let your eyes look directly ahead;
    fix your gaze straight in front of you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Carefully measure the paths for your feet,
    and all your ways will be established.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not turn to the right or to the left;
    turn your foot away from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, pay attention to my wisdom,
and listen closely to my insight,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so you may carefully practice discretion
    and your lips preserve knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the lips of an adulteress drip honey,
    and her speech is smoother than oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But in the end she is as bitter as wormwood,
    and as sharp as a double-edged sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her feet go down to death;
    her steps lead to Sheol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You aren’t thinking about where her life is headed;
    her steps wander, but you do not realize it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now, children, listen to me.
    Don’t turn away from what I am saying.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep far away from her,
    and don’t go near the entrance to her house,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that you don’t give your honor to others,
    and waste your best years;
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that strangers don’t enrich themselves at your expense,
    and your work won’t end up the possession of foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will cry out in anguish when your end comes,
    when your flesh and body are consumed,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and you will say, “How I hated instruction,
    and my heart rejected correction!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I did not obey my teachers
    and did not listen to my instructors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now I am at the point of utter disaster
    in the assembly and in the congregation.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Drink water from your own cistern,
    and fresh water from your own well.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should your springs flow outside,
    or streams of water in the street?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They should be for you alone
    and not for strangers who are with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let your fountain be blessed
    and enjoy the wife of your youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a loving deer, a beautiful doe,
    let her breasts satisfy you all the time.
        Be constantly intoxicated by her love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should you be intoxicated by an adulteress, my son,
    and embrace the bosom of a foreign woman?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, what a man does is always in the Lord’s presence,
    and he weighs all his paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked person’s iniquities will capture him,
    and he will be held with the cords of his sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will die for lack of discipline,
    and he goes astray because of his great folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, if you guarantee a loan for your neighbor,
if you have agreed to a deal with a stranger,
speaker: Narrator

text:
trapped by your own words,
    and caught by your own words,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then do this, my son, and deliver yourself,
    because you have come under your neighbor’s control.
Go, humble yourself!
    Plead passionately with your neighbor!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t allow yourself to sleep
    or even to close your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deliver yourself like a gazelle from a hunter’s hand,
    or like a bird from a fowler’s hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go to the ant, you lazy man!
    Observe its ways and become wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It has no commander,
    officer, or ruler,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but prepares its provisions in the summer
    and gathers its food in the harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long will you lie down, lazy man?
    When will you get up from your sleep?
speaker: Narrator

text:
A little sleep, a little slumber,
    a little folding of the hands to rest,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and your poverty will come on you like a bandit
    and your desperation like an armed man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A worthless man, a wicked man,
    goes around with devious speech,
speaker: Narrator

text:
winking with his eyes, making signs with his feet,
    pointing with his fingers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
planning evil with a perverse mind,
    continually stirring up discord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, disaster will overtake him suddenly.
    He will be broken in an instant,
        and he will never recover.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Here are six things that the Lord hates—
    seven, in fact, are detestable to him:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
a heart crafting evil plans,
    feet running swiftly to wickedness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a false witness snorting lies,
    and someone sowing quarrels between brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep your father’s commands, my son,
    and never forsake your mother’s rules,
speaker: Narrator

text:
by binding them to your heart continuously,
    fastening them around your neck.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Because the command is a lamp
    and the Law a light,
        rebukes that discipline are a way of life—
speaker: Narrator

text:
to protect you from the evil woman,
    from the words of the seductive woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not focus on her beauty in your mind,
    nor allow her to take you prisoner with her flirting eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because the price of a whore is a loaf of bread,
    and an adulterous woman stalks a man’s precious life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can a man scoop fire into his bosom
    without burning his clothes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can a man walk on hot coals
    without scorching his feet?
speaker: Narrator

text:
So also is it with someone who has sex with his neighbor’s wife;
    anyone touching her will not remain unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A thief isn’t despised
    if he steals to meet his needs when he is hungry,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but when he is discovered,
    he must restore seven-fold,
        forfeiting the entire value of his house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever commits adultery with a woman is out of his mind;
    by doing so he corrupts his own soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will receive a beating and dishonor,
    and his shame won’t disappear,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because jealousy incites a strong man’s rage,
    and he will show no mercy when it’s time for revenge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will not consider any payment,
    nor will he be willing to accept it,
        no matter how large the bribe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, guard what I say
and treasure my commands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep my commands and you’ll live.
    Guard my teaching as you do your eyesight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strap them to your fingers
    and engrave them on the tablet of your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to wisdom, “You’re my sister!”
    and call understanding your close relative,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so they can keep you from an adulterous woman,
    from the immoral woman with her seductive words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For from a window in my house
    I peered through the lattice work,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and I noticed among the naïve—
    that is, I discerned among the youths—
        a senseless young man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Proceeding down the street near her corner,
    he makes his way toward her house
speaker: Narrator

text:
at twilight, during the evening,
    even during the darkest part of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look! A woman makes her way to meet him,
    dressed as a prostitute
        and intending to entrap him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is brazen and defiant—
    her feet don’t remain at home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now she is in the street, now in the plazas,
    she lurks near every corner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So she grabs hold of him and kisses him,
    with a brazen face she speaks to him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have given my peace offerings,
    and today I fulfilled my vows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, I’ve come out to meet you,
    I’ve looked just for you,
        and I found you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ve decorated my bed with new coverings—
    embroidered linen from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ve perfumed my bed
    with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, let’s make love until dawn;
    let’s comfort ourselves with love,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because my husband isn’t home.
    He left on a long trip.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He took a fist full of cash
    and he’ll return home in a month.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
She leads him astray with great persuasion;
    with flattering lips she seduces him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All of a sudden he follows her
    like an ox fit for slaughter
        or like a fool fit for a trap
speaker: Narrator

text:
until an arrow pierces his liver.
    As a bird darts into a snare,
        he doesn’t realize his fatal decision.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So listen to me, my sons,
    and pay attention to what I have to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t be led astray by her lifestyle,
    and don’t imitate her behavior.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For many are the victims whom she has conquered,
    and many are her slain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her house leads to Sheol,
    descending to death’s catacombs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isn’t wisdom calling out;
isn’t understanding raising her voice?
speaker: Narrator

text:
On top of the highest places along the road
    she stands where the roads meet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Beside the gates, at the city entrance—
    at the entrance to the portals she cries aloud:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’m calling to you, men!
    What I have to say pertains to all mankind!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Understand prudence, you naïve people;
    and gain an understanding heart, you foolish ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, because I have noble things to say,
    and what I have to say will reveal what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my mouth speaks the truth—
    wickedness is detestable to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everything I have to say is just;
    there isn’t anything corrupt or perverse in my speech.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everything I say is sensible to someone who understands,
    and correct to those who have acquired knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Grab hold of my instruction in lieu of money
    and knowledge instead of the finest gold,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because wisdom is better than precious gems
    and nothing you desire can compare to it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I, wisdom, am related to prudence.
    I know how to be discreet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord is to hate evil.
    Pride, arrogance, an evil lifestyle,
        and perverted speech I despise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Counsel belongs to me,
    along with sound judgment.
I am understanding.
    Power belongs to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Kings reign by me,
    and rulers dispense justice through me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By me leaders rule, as do noble officials
    and all who govern justly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I love those who love me,
    and those who seek me will find me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth and honor accompany me,
    as do enduring wealth and righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My fruit is better than gold,
    better than even refined gold,
        and my benefit surpasses the purest silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I walk on the way of righteousness,
    along paths that are just,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I bequeath wealth to those who love me,
    and I will fill their treasuries.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord made me as he began his planning,
    before his ancient activity commenced.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
When there were no ocean depths,
    I brought them to birth
        at a time when there were no springs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before the mountains were shaped,
    before there were hills,
        I was bringing them to birth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even though he had not made the earth, nor the fields,
    nor the world’s first grains of dust,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he crafted the heavens,
    I was there—
        when he marked out a circle on the face of the deep,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he made the clouds from above,
    when the springs of the depths were established,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he set a boundary for the sea
    so the waters would not exceed his limits,
        when he marked out the foundations of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I was with him, his master craftsman—
    I was his delight daily,
        continuously rejoicing in his presence,
speaker: Narrator

text:
rejoicing in his inhabitable world
    and taking delight in mankind.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“So listen to me, children!
    Blessed are those who obey me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to instruction and be wise.
    Don’t ignore it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed is the person who listens to me,
    watching daily at my gates,
        waiting at my doorways—
speaker: Narrator

text:
because those who find me find life
    and gain favor from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But whoever sins against me destroys himself;
    everyone who hates me loves death.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom has built her house;
she has hewn out her seven pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She has prepared her food,
    she has spiced her wine,
        and she also has set her dining table.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She has sent out her young women,
    while calling out from the heights of the city,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let whoever is naïve, turn in here.”
    To anyone lacking sense, she says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come! Eat my food,
    and drink the wine that I have mixed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Leave your naïve ways, and live.
    Walk in the path of understanding.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever corrects a mocker invites only insult,
    and whoever rebukes the wicked will himself become stained.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t rebuke a mocker or he will hate you.
    Rebuke a wise person, and he will love you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Counsel a wise man,
    and he will be wiser still;
teach a righteous man,
    and he will add to his learning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord is where wisdom begins,
    and knowing holiness demonstrates understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For because of me you will live a long life,
    and years will be added to your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are wise,
    your wisdom will assist you.
If you mock,
    you alone will be held responsible.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The foolish woman is loud,
    undisciplined, and without knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She sits at the entrance of her house,
    on a seat high above the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She calls out to those passing by on the road,
    who are minding their own business,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Whoever is naïve, turn in here!”
    And to anyone lacking sense, she says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Stolen waters are sweet,
    and food eaten in secret is delicious.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he does not realize that the dead lurk there,
    and her invited guests wind up in the depths of Sheol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The proverbs of Solomon.
A wise son brings joy to his father,
    but a foolish son grieves his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nothing good comes from ill-gotten wealth,
    but righteousness delivers from death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord won’t cause the righteous to hunger,
    but he will reject what the wicked crave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lazy hands bring poverty,
    but hard-working hands lead to wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever harvests during summer acts wisely,
    but the son who sleeps during harvest is disgraceful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessings come upon the head of the righteous,
    but the words of the wicked conceal violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The reputation of the righteous leads to blessing,
    but the name of the wicked will rot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise person accepts commands,
    but the chattering fool will be brought down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever walks in integrity lives prudently,
    but whoever perverts his way of life will be exposed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who wink their eyes are trouble makers,
    and the mocking fool will be brought down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the righteous say is a flowing fountain,
    but what the wicked say conceals violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hatred awakens contention,
    but love covers all transgressions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom characterizes the speech of the discerning,
    but the rod is for the backs of those lacking discernment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are wise store up knowledge,
    but when the fool speaks, destruction is near.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich hide within the fortress that is their wealth,
    but the poor are dismayed due to their poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honorable wages lead to life;
    the salaries of the wicked, to retribution.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever heeds correction is on the pathway to life,
    but someone who ignores exhortation goes astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever conceals hatred is a deceitful liar,
    and whoever spreads slander is a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Transgression is at work where people talk too much,
    but anyone who holds his tongue is prudent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the righteous person says is like precious silver;
    the thoughts of the wicked are compared to small things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the righteous person says nourishes many,
    but fools die because they lack discerning hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The blessing of the Lord establishes wealth,
    and difficulty does not accompany it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as the fool considers wickedness his joy,
    so is wisdom to the discerning man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the wicked fears will come about,
    but the longing of the righteous will be granted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the storm ends, the wicked vanish,
    but the righteous person is forever firm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As vinegar is to the mouth and smoke to the eyes,
    so is the lazy person to those who send him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fearing the Lord prolongs life,
    but the wicked will not live long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the righteous hope for brings joy,
    but the expectation of the wicked dies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To the upright, the way of the Lord is a place of safety,
    but it’s a place of ruin to those who practice evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous will never be overthrown,
    but the wicked will never inhabit the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the righteous overflow with wisdom,
    but the perverse tongue will be cut out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteous lips know what is prudent,
    but the words of the wicked are perverse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord hates false scales,
but he delights in accurate weights.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When pride appears, disgrace accompanies it,
    but humility is present with wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The integrity of the righteous guides them,
    but the hypocrisy of the treacherous destroys them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth won’t help in the time of judgment,
    but righteousness will deliver from death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteousness of the innocent creates a level path,
    but the wicked fall by their wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteousness of the upright delivers them,
    but the treacherous are trapped by their evil desires.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a wicked person dies, his hope vanishes;
    and what he expected from his scheming comes to nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous person is delivered from trouble;
    it comes upon the wicked instead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By what he says, the godless person can destroy his neighbor,
    but through knowledge the righteous escape.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The city rejoices when the righteous prosper,
    and when the wicked perish there is jubilation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Through the blessing of the righteous a city is built up,
    but what the wicked say tears it down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever belittles his neighbor lacks sense,
    but the discerning man controls his comments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever spreads gossip betrays secrets,
    but the trustworthy person keeps a confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A nation falls through a lack of guidance,
    but victory comes through the counsel of many.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Securing a loan for a stranger will bring suffering,
    but by refusing to do so, one remains safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gracious woman attains honor,
    but ruthless men attain wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gracious man benefits himself,
    but the cruel person damages himself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people earn deceptive wages,
    but those who plant righteousness are truly rewarded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Genuine righteousness leads to life,
    but whoever pursues evil will die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Devious minds are abhorrent to the Lord,
    but those whose ways are innocent are his delight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be sure of this: the wicked will not go unpunished,
    but the descendants of the righteous will go free.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a gold ring in a pig’s snout
    is a beautiful woman without discretion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The desire of the righteous is to seek good,
    but the hope of the wicked results in wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who give freely gain even more;
    others hold back what they owe, becoming even poorer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A generous person will prosper,
    and anyone who gives water will receive a flood in return.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People will curse whoever withholds grain,
    but blessing will come to whoever is selling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person seeking good will find favor,
    but anyone who searches for evil—it will find him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person who trusts in his wealth will fall,
    but the righteous will flourish like green leaves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever troubles his household will inherit the wind,
    and the fool will be a servant to the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life,
    and the one who wins people is wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the righteous receive what they are due here on earth,
    how much more will the wicked and the sinner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person who loves correction loves knowledge,
but anyone who hates a rebuke is stupid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The good person will gain favor from the Lord,
    but the man who plots evil will be condemned by him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person doesn’t gain security by wickedness,
    but the righteous won’t be uprooted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A virtuous woman is a crown to her husband,
    but a wife who puts him to shame is like bone cancer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The plans of the righteous are just,
    but the advice of the wicked is deceitful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the wicked lead to bloodshed,
    but the speech of the upright delivers them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After they’re overthrown, the wicked won’t be found,
    but the house of the righteous stands firm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man is praised because of his wise words,
    but the perverted mind will be despised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to be unimportant, yet have a servant,
    than to pretend to be important, but lack food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous person looks out for the welfare of his livestock,
    but even the compassion of the wicked is cruel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever tills his soil will have a lot to eat,
    but anyone who pursues fantasies lacks sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked desires what evil people gain,
    but the foundation of the righteous is productive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An evil man’s sinful speech ensnares him,
    but the righteous person escapes from trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By his fruitful speech a man can remain satisfied,
    and a man’s handiwork will reward him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lifestyle of the fool is right in his own opinion,
    but wise is the man who listens to advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The anger of a fool becomes readily apparent,
    but the prudent person overlooks an insult.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The truth teller speaks what is right,
    but the false witness speaks what is deceitful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some speak rashly like the cutting of a sword,
    but what the wise say promotes healing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A truthful saying is trusted forever,
    but the liar only for a moment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deceit is at home in the heart of those who plan evil,
    but those who promote peace rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No harm overwhelms the righteous,
    but the wicked overflow with trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deceitful speech is reprehensible to the Lord,
    but those who act faithfully are his delight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A prudent man keeps what he knows to himself,
    but the hearts of fools shout forth their foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The diligent will take control,
    but the lazy will be put to forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person’s anxiety weighs down his heart,
    but an appropriate word is encouraging.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous person is cautious with respect to his neighbor,
    but the lifestyle of the wicked leads them astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person does not roast what he has hunted,
    but diligence is one’s most important possession.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the pathway to righteousness there is life,
    and in that lifestyle there is no death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise son heeds a father’s correction,
but a mocker does not listen to rebuke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the fruit of his words a man receives benefit,
    but the treacherous crave violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who guards his words protects his life;
    anyone who talks too much is ruined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person craves, yet receives nothing,
    but the desires of the diligent are satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A righteous person hates deceit,
    but the wicked person is shameful and disgraceful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteousness protects the blameless,
    but wickedness brings down the sinner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One person pretends to be wealthy, but has nothing;
    another pretends to be poor, yet is rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The life of a wealthy man may be held for ransom,
    but whoever is poor receives no threats.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The light of the righteous shines,
    but the lamp of the wicked is extinguished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arrogance only brings quarreling,
    but those receiving advice are wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth gained dishonestly dwindles away,
    but whoever works diligently increases his prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Delayed hope makes the heart ill,
    but fulfilled longing is a tree of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who despises a word of advice will pay for it,
    but whoever heeds a command will be rewarded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the wise have to teach is a fountain of life
    and causes someone to avoid the snares of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Good understanding produces grace,
    but the lifestyle of the treacherous never changes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every sensible person acts from knowledge,
    but a fool demonstrates folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An evil messenger stumbles into trouble,
    but a faithful envoy brings healing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Poverty and shame are for those who ignore correction,
    but whoever listens to instruction gains honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fulfilled longing is sweet to the soul,
    but avoiding evil is detestable to the fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever keeps company with the wise becomes wise,
    but the companion of fools suffers harm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Disaster pursues the sinful,
    but good will reward the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A good person leaves an inheritance to his grandchildren,
    but the wealth of the wicked is reserved for the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The field of the poor may produce much food,
    but it can be swept away through injustice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever does not discipline his son hates him,
    but whoever loves him is diligent to correct him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A righteous person eats to his heart’s content,
    but the stomach of the wicked remains hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every wise woman builds up her household,
but the foolish one tears it down with her own hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Someone whose conduct is upright fears the Lord,
    but whoever is devious in his ways despises him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What a fool says brings a rod to his back,
    but the words of the wise protect them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where there are no oxen, the feeding trough is clean,
    but profits come through the strength of the ox.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A trustworthy witness does not deceive,
    but a false witness spews lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A mocker seeks wisdom and finds none,
    but learning comes easily to someone who understands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stay away from a foolish man,
    for you will not find competent advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wisdom of the prudent helps him know how to live,
    but a fool’s stupidity deceives him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools make fun of guilt,
    but among the upright there are good intentions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heart knows its own bitterness—
    an outsider cannot share in its joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The house of the wicked will be destroyed,
    but the tent of the upright will flourish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a pathway that seems right to a man,
    but in the end it’s a road to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even in laughter there may be heartache,
    and at the end of joy there may be grief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The faithless one will pay for his behavior,
    but a good man will be rewarded for his.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An unthinking person believes everything,
    but the prudent one thinks before acting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise person fears and turns away from evil,
    but a fool is reckless and overconfident.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A quick tempered person does foolish things,
    and a devious man is hated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The naïve inherit folly,
    but the careful are crowned with knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil men will bow down in the presence of good men
    and the wicked at the gates of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor person is shunned by his neighbor,
    but many are the friends of the wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever despises his neighbor sins,
    but whoever shows kindness to the poor will be happy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Won’t those who plot evil go astray?
    But gracious love and truth are for those who plan what is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In hard work there is always profit,
    but too much chattering leads to poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crown of the wise is their wealth,
    but the stupidity of fools is just that—stupidity!
speaker: Narrator

text:
A truthful witness saves lives,
    but the person who lies is deceitful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rock-solid security is found in the fear of the Lord,
    and within it one’s children find refuge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord is a fountain of life,
    enabling anyone to escape the snares of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A large population is a king’s glory,
    but a shortage of people is a ruler’s ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Being slow to get angry compares to great understanding
    as being quick-tempered compares to stupidity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A tranquil mind brings life to one’s body,
    but jealousy causes one’s bones to rot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever oppresses the poor defies their Creator,
    but whoever is kind to the needy honors them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked person is thrown down by his own wrongdoing,
    but the righteous person has a place of safety in death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is at rest in the mind of the discerning—
    even fools know this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteousness makes a nation great,
    but sin diminishes any people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king approves the wise servant,
    but he is angry at anyone who acts shamefully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gentle response diverts anger,
but a harsh statement incites fury.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise speak, presenting knowledge appropriately,
    but fools spout foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eyes of the Lord are in every place,
    observing both the evil and the good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gentle statement is a tree of life,
    but perverted speech shatters the spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool rejects his father’s instructions,
    but anyone who respects reproof acts sensibly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous house is itself a great treasure,
    but within the revenue of the wicked calamity is at work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the wise have to say disseminates knowledge,
    but it’s not in the heart of fools to do so.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable to the Lord,
    but the prayer of the upright is his delight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lifestyle of the wicked is detestable to the Lord,
    but he loves those who ardently pursue righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Severe punishment awaits anyone who wanders off the path—
    anyone who despises reproof will die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Since Sheol and Abaddon lie open in the Lord’s presence,
    how much more the hearts of human beings!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The arrogant mocker never loves the one who corrects him;
    he will not inquire of the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A happy heart enlightens the face,
    but a sad heart reflects a broken spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A discerning mind seeks knowledge,
    but the mouth of fools feeds on stupidity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The entire life of the afflicted seems disastrous,
    but a good heart feasts continuously.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better is a little accompanied by fear of the Lord
    than abundant wealth with turmoil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A vegetarian meal served with love is better
    than a big, thick steak with a plateful of animosity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The quickly angered man stirs up contention,
    but anyone who controls his temper calms a dispute.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lifestyle of the lazy is like a thorny hedge,
    but the path taken by the upright is an open highway.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise son makes a father glad,
    but a foolish man despises his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stupidity is the delight of the senseless,
    but an understanding man walks uprightly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Plans fail without advice,
    but with many counselors they are confirmed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An appropriate answer brings joy to a person,
    and a well-timed word is a good thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of life leads upward for the wise
    so he may avoid Sheol below.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The house of the proud the Lord will demolish,
    but he will protect the widow’s boundary line.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To the Lord evil plans are detestable,
    but pleasant words are pure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are greedy for unjust gain bring trouble into their homes,
    but the person who hates bribes will live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mind of the righteous thinks before speaking,
    but the wicked person spews out evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is far away from the wicked,
    but he hears the prayers of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bright eyes encourage the heart;
    good news nourishes the body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever listens to a life-giving rebuke
    will be at home among the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever ignores instruction hates himself,
    but anyone who heeds reproof gains understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord teaches wisdom,
    and humility precedes honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People do the planning,
but the end result is from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everything a person does seems pure in his own opinion,
    but the Lord weighs intentions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Entrust your work to the Lord,
    and your planning will succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord made everything answerable to him,
    including the wicked at the time of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests those who are proud;
    truly they will not go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Iniquity is atoned for by gracious love and truth,
    and through fear of the Lord people turn from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a person’s ways please the Lord,
    even his enemies will be at peace with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A little gain with righteousness is better
    than great income without justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person plans his way,
    but the Lord directs his steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a king is ready to speak officially,
    what he says should not err with respect to justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honest scales and balances are from the Lord;
    he made all the weights in the bag.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Kings detest wrongdoing,
    for through righteousness the throne is established.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Kings take pleasure in righteous speech;
    they treasure a person who speaks what is upright.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king’s wrath results in a death sentence,
    but whoever is wise will appease him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a king is pleased, there is life,
    and his favor is like a cloud that brings spring rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much better than gaining gold is the acquisition of wisdom,
    the attainment of wisdom better than silver!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The road of the upright circumvents evil,
    and whoever watches how he lives preserves his life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pride precedes destruction;
    an arrogant spirit appears before a fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be humble among the poor,
    than to share what is stolen with the proud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever listens to a word of instruction prospers,
    and anyone who trusts in the Lord is blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise-hearted person is told to be discerning,
    and that pleasant speech promotes instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who has understanding is a fountain of life,
    but foolishness brings punishment to fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise person’s thoughts control his words,
    and his speech promotes instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pleasant words are honey from a honeycomb—
    sweet to the soul and healing for the body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a road that seems right for a man to travel,
    but in the end it’s the road to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The appetite of the laborer motivates him;
    indeed, his hunger drives him on.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A worthless person concocts evil gossip—
    his lips are like a burning fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A deceitful man stirs dissension,
    and anyone who gossips separates friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A violent man entices his companion
    and leads him on a path that is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever winks knowingly is plotting deceit;
    anyone who purses his lips is bent towards evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gray hair is a crown of glory;
    it is obtained by following a righteous path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever controls his temper is better than a warrior,
    and anyone who has control of his spirit is better
        than someone who captures a city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The dice is cast into someone’s lap,
    but the outcome is from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dry crumbs in peace are better
than a full meal with strife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A prudent servant will rule in place of a disgraceful son
    and will share in the inheritance among brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crucible is for silver
    and the furnace for gold—
        but the Lord assays hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever practices evil pays attention to wicked speech,
    and the liar listens to malicious talk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever mocks the poor shows contempt for their maker,
    and whoever is happy about disaster
        will not go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Grandchildren are the crown of the aged,
    and the pride of children is their parents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Appropriate speech is inconsistent with the fool;
    how much more are deceitful statements with a prince!
speaker: Narrator

text:
A bribe works wonders in the eyes of its giver;
    wherever he turns he prospers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who overlooks an offense promotes love,
    but someone who gossips separates close friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A rebuke is more effective with a man of understanding
    than a hundred lashes to a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A rebellious person seeks evil;
    a cruel emissary will be sent to oppose him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to meet a mother bear who has lost her cubs
    than a fool in his stupidity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person who repays good with evil
    will never see evil leave his home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Starting a quarrel is like spilling water—
    so drop the dispute before it escalates.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Exonerating the wicked and condemning the righteous
    are both detestable to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is this? A fool has enough money to buy wisdom,
    but is senseless?
speaker: Narrator

text:
A friend loves at all times,
    and a brother is there for times of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man who lacks sense cosigns a loan,
    becoming a guarantor for his neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person who loves transgression loves strife;
    the person who builds a high gate invites destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person whose mind is perverse does not find good,
    and anyone with perverted speech falls into trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man who fathers a fool does so to his sorrow—
    the father of a fool has no joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A joyful heart is good medicine,
    but a broken spirit drains one’s strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked man takes a bribe in secret
    in order to pervert the course of justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person with understanding has wisdom as his objective,
    but a fool looks only to earthly goals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A foolish son brings grief to his father
    and bitterness to his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Furthermore, it isn’t good to fine the righteous,
    or to beat an official because of his uprightness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever controls what he says is knowledgeable;
    anyone who has a calm spirit is a man of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even a fool is thought to be wise when he remains silent;
    he is thought to be prudent when he keeps his mouth shut.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever isolates himself pursues selfish ends;
he resists all sound advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool finds no satisfaction in trying to understand,
    for he would rather express his own opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When an evil person comes, contempt also comes,
    along with dishonor and disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words a man says are as deep waters—
    a fountain of wisdom is an overflowing stream.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s not good to be partial towards an evil person,
    thereby depriving the righteous of justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool’s words bring strife,
    and his mouth invites fighting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool’s mouth is his unraveling,
    and his lips entrap himself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of a gossip are like choice morsels
    as they descend to the innermost parts of the body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever is lazy regarding his work
    is also a brother to the master of destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The name of the Lord is a strong tower;
    a righteous person rushes to it and is lifted up above the danger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wealth of a rich person is his fortified city;
    in his own imagination, it is like a high wall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before a man’s downfall, his mind is arrogant,
    but humility precedes honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever answers before listening
    is both foolish and shameful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man’s spirit can sustain him during his illness,
    but who can bear a crushed spirit?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mind of a discerning person gains knowledge,
    while the ears of wise people seek out knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person’s gift opens doors for him,
    bringing him access to important people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The first to put forth his case seems right,
    until someone else steps forward and cross-examines him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Casting dice settles a dispute,
    deciding between strong contenders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An offended brother is more unyielding than a fortified city,
    and his disputes are like the bars of a fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The positive words that a man speaks fill his stomach;
    he will be satisfied with what his lips produce.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The power of the tongue is life and death—
    those who love to talk will eat what it produces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever finds a wife finds what is good,
    and receives favor from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor person pleads for mercy,
    but the wealthy man responds harshly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man with many friends can still be ruined,
    but one who keeps on loving sticks closer than a brother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A poor man who walks blamelessly is better
than a fool who speaks perversely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Furthermore, it isn’t good to be ignorant,
    and whoever rushes into things misses the mark.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man’s foolishness ruins his life,
    yet his heart rages against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth brings many friends,
    but a poor man is deserted by his friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A witness to lies will not go unpunished;
    the teller of falsehoods will not escape.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many curry favor of an official;
    everyone is a friend of the gift giver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the relatives of a poor person shun him—
    how much more do his friends avoid him!
Though he runs after them pleading,
    they aren’t around.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever obtains wisdom loves himself,
    and whoever treasures understanding will prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A witness to lies will not go unpunished;
    the teller of falsehoods will perish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s not fitting for a fool to live in luxury;
    neither is it for a servant to rule over princes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person’s discretion makes him slow to anger,
    and it is to his credit that he ignores an offence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king’s anger is like the roaring of a lion,
    but his goodwill is like dew on the grass.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A father’s ruin is a foolish son,
    and a wife’s quarreling is like dripping water that never stops.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A house and self-sufficiency are a father’s inheritance,
    but from the Lord comes an insightful wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Laziness puts one to sleep,
    and an idle person will go hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever obeys a commandment keeps himself safe,
    but someone who is contemptuous in conduct will die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever is kind to the poor is lending to the Lord—
    the benefit of his gift will return to him in abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Discipline your son while there is still hope—
    but don’t set your heart on his destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person who has great anger must pay the consequences,
    because if you rescue him, you will have to do it again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to advice and accept discipline,
    and you’ll be wise for the rest of your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many plans occupy the mind of a man,
    but the Lord’s purposes will prevail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Human beings long for grace,
    and it’s better to be poor than a man of deceit.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The lazy person buries his hand in his dish
    and doesn’t bother to bring it back to his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you scourge a scoffer,
    the simple person may learn to be discreet;
rebuke a discerning man
    and he will gain understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever mistreats his father
    and alienates his mother
        is a son who brings both shame and disrespect.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, if you stop listening to instruction,
    you will stray from the principles of knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A corrupt witness mocks justice,
    and the wicked person feeds on iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Condemnation is appropriate for mockers,
    just as beatings are for the backs of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wine causes mocking, and beer causes fights;
everyone led astray by them lacks wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A king’s anger is like a lion’s roar;
    anyone who angers him forfeits his life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Avoiding strife brings a man honor,
    but every fool is quarrelsome.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lazy person doesn’t plow in the proper season;
    he looks for a harvest, but there is nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The intentions of a person’s heart are deep waters,
    but a discerning person reveals them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many claim “I’m a loyal person!”
    but who can find someone who truly is?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous person lives a life of integrity;
    happy are his children who follow him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
A king sits on a throne of justice,
    sifting out all sorts of evil with his glance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can say, “My intentions are pure;
    I am clean from any sin?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
False weights and measures—
    the Lord surely detests both of them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even a child is known by his actions,
    whether his deeds are pure and right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ear that hears and the eye that sees—
    the Lord surely made them both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not love sleep or you’ll become poor,
    keep your eyes open and you’ll have plenty of food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is bad, bad,” says whoever is buying—
    but then he brags as he walks away after the sale.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is an abundance of gold and precious stones,
    but lips of knowledge are a rare jewel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take the garment of anyone who puts up collateral for a stranger;
    hold it in pledge if he does it for an unfamiliar woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bread gained by deceit is sweet to a man,
    but later his mouth will be full of gravel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make plans by seeking advice;
    make war by obtaining guidance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever spreads gossip betrays confidences;
    so don’t get involved with someone who talks too much.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever curses his father or mother,
    his lamp will be extinguished in the deepest darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An inheritance quickly obtained at the beginning
    will not be blessed at the end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t say “I’ll avenge that wrong!”
    Wait on the Lord and he will deliver you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests differing weights,
    and dishonest scales are not good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man’s steps are directed by the Lord;
    how then can anyone understand his own way?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is a trap for a person to declare quickly, “This is sacred,”
    and only later to have second thoughts about the vows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise king sifts the wicked,
    crushing them with the threshing wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person’s spirit is the lamp of the Lord;
    it searches throughout one’s innermost being.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gracious love and truth preserve a king;
    through love his throne is made secure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The glory of young men is their strength;
    and the splendor of elders is their gray hair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blows that wound clean away evil;
    such beatings cleanse the innermost being.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A king’s heart is a water stream that the Lord controls;
he directs it wherever he pleases.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every man’s lifestyle is proper in his own view,
    but the Lord weighs the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To do what is right and just
    is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A proud attitude, accompanied by a haughty look, is sin;
    they reveal wicked people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Plans of the persistent surely lead to productivity,
    but all who are hasty will surely become poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fortune gained by deceit
    is a fleeting vapor and a deadly snare.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Devastation caused by the wicked will drag them away
    because they refuse to do what is just.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The conduct of a guilty man is perverse,
    but the behavior of the pure is upright.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to live in a corner on the roof
    than to share a house with a contentious woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The soul of the wicked craves evil;
    he extends no mercy to his neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a mocker is punished, the fool gains wisdom;
    but when the wise is instructed, he receives knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous God considers the house of the wicked,
    bringing the wicked to ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever refuses to hear the cry of the poor
    will also cry himself, but he won’t be answered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Privately given gifts pacify wrath,
    and payments made secretly appease great anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Administering justice brings joy to the righteous,
    but terror to those who practice iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever wanders from the path of understanding
    will end up where the dead are gathered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pleasure lovers become poor;
    loving wine and oil doesn’t bring riches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked are ransom for the righteous,
    and the unfaithful for the upright.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to live in the wilderness
    than to live with a contentious and irritable woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Precious treasures and oil are found where the wise live,
    but a foolish man devours them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever pursues righteousness and gracious love
    finds life, righteousness, and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise man attacks the city of the mighty,
    bringing down the fortress in which they trust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever watches his mouth and tongue
    keeps himself from trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The names “Proud,” “Arrogant,” and “Mocker”
    fit whoever acts with presumptuous conceit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the lazy person craves will kill him,
    because his hands refuse to work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All day long he continues to crave,
    while the righteous person gives without holding back.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the wicked person sacrifices is detestable—
    how much more when he offers it with vile motives!
speaker: Narrator

text:
A false witness will perish,
    but whoever listens will testify successfully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked man puts up a bold appearance,
    but the upright thinks about what he is doing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No wisdom, insight, or counsel
    can prevail against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The horse may be prepared for the day of battle,
    but to the Lord goes the victory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A good reputation is more desirable than great wealth,
and favorable acceptance more than silver and gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich and the poor have this in common—
    the Lord created both of them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The prudent person sees trouble ahead and hides,
    but the naïve continue on and suffer the consequences.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The reward of humility is the fear of the Lord,
    along with wealth, honor, and life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thorns and snares lie in the path of the perverse person,
    but whoever is cautious stays far away from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Train a child in the way appropriate for him,
    and when he becomes older, he will not turn from it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wealthy rule over the poor,
    and anyone who borrows is a slave to the lender.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever sows wickedness reaps trouble,
    and the anger he uses for a weapon will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever is generous will be blessed,
    for he shares his food with the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Throw out the mocker and strife departs, too;
    furthermore, quarrels and discord will end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever loves purity and gracious speech
    will gain the king as his friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord watches over anyone with knowledge,
    but he ruins the plans of the unfaithful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person says, “There is a lion outside!
    I will be killed in the street!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mouth of an immoral woman is a deep pit;
    a man experiencing the Lord’s wrath will fall into it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A child’s heart has a tendency to do wrong,
    but the rod of discipline removes it far away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever oppresses the poor to enrich himself
    and whoever gives gifts to the wealthy
        will yield only loss.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay attention and listen to the words of the wise,
    and apply your heart to my teaching,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for it is pleasant when you treasure them within you
    and have them ready on your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a result, your trust will be in the Lord,
    that’s why I’m teaching you today, even you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have I not written for you 30 sayings
    containing counsel and knowledge,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to teach you true and reliable advice,
    so you can give truthful answers to those who sent you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t rob the poor person because he is poor,
    and don’t crush the helpless in court,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the Lord will plead their case
    and ruin the lives of those who ruin them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t make friends with a hot-tempered man,
    and do not associate with someone who is easily angered,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or you may learn his ways
    and find yourself caught in a trap.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t be one of those who make promises
    to guarantee loans for debts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you don’t have the ability to pay,
    why should your very bed be taken from under you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t remove an ancient boundary stone
    that was set up by your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you see a man skilled in his work?
    He will work for kings, not unimportant people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whenever you sit down to dine with a ruler,
carefully think about what is before you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Put a knife to your own throat,
    if you have a big appetite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t crave his delicacies,
    because the meal is deceptive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t exhaust yourself acquiring wealth;
    be smart enough to stop.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you fix your gaze on it, it’s gone,
    for it sprouts wings for itself
        and flies to the sky like an eagle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t consume food provided by a miserly person,
    and don’t desire his delicacies,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for as he thinks within himself, so he is.
    “Eat and drink!” he’ll say to you,
        but his heart won’t be with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ll vomit up what little you’ve eaten,
    and your compliments will have been wasted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t speak when a fool is listening,
    because he’ll despise your wise words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t move ancient boundaries
    or invade fields belonging to orphans;
speaker: Narrator

text:
for strong is their Redeemer
    who will take up their case against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Learn diligently,
    and listen to words of knowledge.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Punish him with a rod,
    and you will rescue his soul from Sheol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, if your heart is wise,
    my own heart will greatly rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My innermost being will be glad
    when your lips speak what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never let yourself envy sinners;
    instead, remain in fear of the Lord every day,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for there is surely a future life,
    and what you hope for will not be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, my son, and be wise,
    commit yourself to live God’s way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t associate with heavy drinkers
    or dine with gluttons,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because drunks and gluttons tend to become poor,
    and drowsiness will clothe them in rags.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to the one who fathered you,
    and don’t despise your mother in her old age.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Purchase truth, but don’t sell it;
    store up wisdom, instruction, and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The father of a righteous person will greatly rejoice;
    whoever fathers a wise son will be glad because of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let your father and mother rejoice;
    make the one who gave birth to you happy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give me your heart, my son,
    and keep your eyes fixed on my ways,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because a prostitute is a deep pit,
    and the adulterous woman a narrow well.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely she lies in wait like a bandit,
    increasing those who are faithless among mankind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has woe? Who has grief?
    Who has contention? Who has complaints?
Who has wounds without cause?
    Who has bloodshot eyes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who linger over their wine,
    who consume mixed drinks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t stare into red wine,
    when it sparkles in the cup
        and goes down smoothly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eventually it will bite like a snake
    and sting like a serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your eyes will see strange things,
    and with slurred words you’ll speak what you really believe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will be like someone who lies down in the sea,
    or like someone who sleeps on top of a mast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They struck me,” you will say,
    “but I never felt it.
They beat me,
    but I never knew it.
When will I wake up?
    I want another drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t be envious of wicked men
or wish you were with them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because they plan violence,
    and they are always talking about trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By wisdom a house is built;
    it is made secure through understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By knowledge its rooms are furnished
    with all sorts of expensive and beautiful goods.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise man is strong,
    and a knowledgeable man grows in strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For through wise counsel you will wage your war,
    and victory lies in an abundance of advisors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom lies beyond reach of the fool;
    he has nothing to say in court.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person who plans on doing evil
    will be called a schemer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To devise folly is sin,
    and people detest a scoffer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you grow weary when times are troubled,
    your strength is limited.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue those who are being led away to death,
    and save those who stumble toward slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you say, “Look here, we didn’t know about this,”
    doesn’t God, who examines motives, discern it?
Doesn’t the one who guards your soul
    know about it?
Won’t he repay each person
    according to what he has done?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, eat honey, because it’s good for you;
    indeed, drippings from the honeycomb are sweet to your taste;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Don’t lie in wait like an outlaw
    to attack where the righteous live;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Don’t rejoice when your enemy falls;
    don’t let yourself be glad when he stumbles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Otherwise the Lord will observe and disapprove,
    and he will turn his anger away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t be anxious about those who practice evil,
    and don’t be envious of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the wicked man has no future;
    the lamp of the wicked will be extinguished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, fear both the Lord and the king,
    and don’t keep company with rebels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will be destroyed suddenly,
    and who knows what kind of punishment will come from these two?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Here are some more proverbs from wise people: 
It isn’t good to show partiality in judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever says to the wicked, “You’re in the right,”
        will be cursed by people and hated by nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for people who rebuke the wicked;
    a good blessing will fall upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A kiss on the lips—
    that’s what someone who gives an honest answer deserves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
First do your outside work,
    preparing your land for yourself.
        After that, build your house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t testify against your neighbor without a cause,
    and don’t lie when you speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t say, “I’ll do to him like he did to me,
    I’ll be sure to pay him back for what he did.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I went by the field belonging to a lazy man,
    by a vineyard belonging to a senseless person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There it was, overgrown with thistles,
    the ground covered with thorns,
        its stone wall collapsed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
