As I observed, I thought about it;
    I watched, and learned a lesson:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“A little sleep! A little slumber!
    A little folding of my hands to rest!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then your poverty will come upon you like a robber,
    your need like an armed bandit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here are some more proverbs by Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, transcribed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is the glory of God to conceal a matter,
    and the glory of kings to investigate a matter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as the heavens are high
    and earth is deep,
        so the heart of a king is unfathomable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Purge the dross from the silver,
    and material for a vessel comes forth for the silversmith.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Purge the wicked from the king’s presence,
    and his throne will be established in righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t magnify yourself in the presence of a king,
    and don’t pretend to be in the company of famous men,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for it is better that it be told you, “Come up here,”
    than for you to be placed lower
        in the presence of an official. 
What you’ve seen with your own eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text:
don’t be in a hurry to argue in court.
Otherwise, what will you do later on
    when your neighbor humiliates you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Instead, take up the matter with your neighbor,
    and don’t betray another person’s confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Otherwise, anyone who hears will make you ashamed,
    and your bad reputation will never leave you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like golden apples set in silver
    is a word spoken at the right time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a gold earring and a necklace of pure gold
    is a wise reprover to a listening ear.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Like clouds and winds without rain
    is the man who brags
        about gifts he never gave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Through patience a ruler may be persuaded;
    a gentle word can break a bone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you find some honey,
    eat only what you need.
Take too much,
    and you’ll vomit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Seldom set foot in your neighbor’s home;
    otherwise, he’ll grow weary and hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A club, a sword, and a sharp arrow—
    that’s what a man is who lies about his neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A bad tooth and an unsteady foot—
    that’s what confidence in an unreliable man is like
        in a time of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Taking your coat off when it’s cold
    or pouring vinegar on soda—
        that’s what singing songs does to a heavy heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If your enemy hungers, give him food to eat;
    and if he thirsts, give him water to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you’ll be piling burning coals of shame on his head
    and the Lord will reward you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The north wind brings rain,
    and a backbiting tongue an angry look.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to live in a corner on the roof
    than in a house with a contentious woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cold water to someone who is thirsty—
    that’s what good news from a distant land is.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A muddied spring or a polluted well—
    that’s what a righteous person is
        who compromises with the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To eat too much honey isn’t good;
    and neither is it honorable to seek one’s own glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a city with breached walls
    is a man without self-control.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like snowfall in summer or rain at harvest time,
so honor is inappropriate for a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a fluttering sparrow
    or a swallow in flight,
        a curse without cause will not alight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A whip is for the horses,
    a bridle is for the donkey,
        a rod is for the back of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t answer a fool according to his foolishness,
    or you will be just like him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer a fool according to his foolishness,
    or he will think himself to be wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever sends a message by the hand of a fool
    cuts off his own feet and drinks violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Useless legs to the lame—
    that’s what a proverb quoted by a fool is.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tying a stone to a sling—
    that’s what giving honor to a fool is.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A thorn in the hand of a drunkard—
    that’s what a proverb quoted by a fool is.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An archer who shoots at anyone—
    is like someone who hires a fool or anyone who passes by.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A dog that returns to its vomit
    is like a fool who reverts to his folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you see a man who is wise in his own opinion?
    There’s more hope for a fool than for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person claims, “There is a lion in the road!
    There’s a lion in the streets!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The door turns on its hinges—
    as does the lazy person on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person buries his hand in the dish,
    but he’s too tired to bring it to his mouth again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person is wiser in his own opinion
    than seven men who can give an appropriate response.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Picking up a dog by the ears—
    that’s what someone is like who meddles in another’s fight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like the maniac who shoots
    fiery darts and deadly arrows—
speaker: Narrator

text:
that’s what someone is like who lies to his neighbor
    and then says, “I was joking, wasn’t I?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without wood, the fire goes out.
    Without a gossip, contention stops.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The words of a gossip are like delicate morsels;
    they sink down deep within.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A clay vessel plated with a thin veneer of silver—
    that’s what smooth lips with a wicked heart are.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Someone who hates hides behind his words,
    harboring deceit within himself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though he speaks graciously, don’t believe him,
    for there are seven detestable things in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though malice disguises itself with deception,
    its evil will be exposed publicly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it,
    and the stone will come back
        on whoever starts it rolling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lying tongue hates its victims,
    and a flattering mouth causes ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never brag about the day to come,
because you don’t know what it might bring.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Rocks are heavy,
    and sand is weighty,
        but a fool’s provocation outweighs them both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wrath can be fierce and anger overwhelms
    but who can stand up to jealousy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
An open rebuke is better
    than unspoken love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wounds from someone who loves are trustworthy,
    but kisses from an enemy speak volumes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person who is full spurns honey,
    but to a hungry person even the bitter seems sweet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a bird that strays from its nest
    is a man who wanders away from his home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ointments and perfume encourage the heart;
    in a similar way, a friend’s advice is sweet to the soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never abandon your friend nor your father’s friend,
    and don’t go to your brother’s house in times of trouble.
A neighbor who is near is better
    than a brother who lives far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be wise, my son, and make me happy,
    so I can reply to anyone who insults me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are prudent see danger and take refuge,
    but the naïve continue on and suffer the consequences.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take the coat of anyone who puts up security for a stranger;
    hold it in pledge if he cosigns for an immoral woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A friend’s loud blessing early in the morning
    will be thought of as a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A continual dripping on a rainy day
    and a contentious wife are alike.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trying to keep her in check is like stopping a wind storm
    or grabbing oil with your right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Iron sharpens iron;
    so a man sharpens a friend’s character.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever nurtures the fig tree will eat its fruit,
    and whoever obeys his master will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as water reflects the face,
    so the heart reflects the person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sheol and Abaddon are never satiated,
    and neither are human eyes.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though you crush a fool in a mortar and pestle
    as someone might crush grain,
        his stupidity still won’t leave him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep well informed of the condition of your flocks
    and pay attention to your herds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because riches don’t endure forever,
    and crowns don’t last from one generation to the next.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the grass disappears,
    and new growth appears,
        the mountain spices will be harvested,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the lambs will supply your clothing,
    and your goats the price of a field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will have enough goat’s milk to drink
    and to supply your household needs,
        as well as sustenance for your servant girls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked flee, though no one pursues,
but the righteous are bold like a lion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a land transgresses,
    it gains a succession of leaders,
but with an understanding and knowledgeable man,
    its stability endures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A poor man who oppresses the weak
    is like a rainstorm that destroys all the crops.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who forsake the Law praise the wicked,
    but whoever keeps it fights them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil men don’t understand justice,
    but whoever seeks the Lord understands it all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to be poor and live a blameless life
    than to be rich but crooked in one’s lifestyle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever keeps the Law is a discerning son,
    but whoever keeps company with gluttons
        brings shame to his father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever gains wealth by charging exorbitant interest
    collects it for someone who is kind to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If someone quits listening to the Law
    even his prayer is detestable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever misleads the upright along an evil way
    will himself fall into his own pit,
        but the blameless will inherit what is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich man may be wise in his own opinion;
    but a discerning, poor man sees through him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the righteous are victorious, there is great glory,
    but when the wicked arise, men hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever hides his transgressions will not succeed,
    but whoever confesses and forsakes them will find mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed is the man who always fears the Lord,
    but whoever hardens his heart will fall into disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A roaring lion and a charging bear—
    that’s what a wicked tyrant is over poor people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A Commander-in-Chief who is a cruel oppressor lacks understanding,
    but whoever hates unjust gain will live longer.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Whoever lives blamelessly will be delivered,
    but whoever is perverted will fall without warning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever works his farmland will have abundant food,
    but whoever chases fantasies will become very poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The faithful man will prosper with blessings,
    but whoever is in a hurry to get rich
        will not escape punishment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To show partiality isn’t good,
    yet for a piece of bread the valiant will transgress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The miser is in a hurry to get wealthy,
    but he isn’t aware that poverty will catch up with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever rebukes a man will later on find more favor
    than someone who flatters with his words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever steals from his father or mother
    but claims, “It’s no sin,”
        is a companion to someone who demolishes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An arrogant man stirs up dissension,
    but anyone who trusts in the Lord prospers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever trusts in himself is foolish,
    but whoever lives wisely will be kept safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever gives to the poor will never lack,
    but whoever shuts his eyes to their poverty will be cursed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked rise to power, people hide themselves,
    but when the wicked perish, the righteous increase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After many rebukes, the stiff-necked man
will be broken incurably, without any warning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the righteous grow powerful, people rejoice;
    but when the wicked rule, people groan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father,
    but anyone who consorts with immoral women squanders his wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A king brings stability to a land through justice,
    but a man who takes bribes brings it to ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A strong man who flatters his neighbor
    is setting a trap where he walks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An evil man is trapped by transgression,
    but the righteous person sings and rejoices.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous person is concerned about the poor;
    but the wicked don’t understand what they need to know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Scornful men enflame a city,
    but the wise defuse anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a wise man has a dispute with a fool,
    the fool either rages or laughs without relief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bloodthirsty men hate the innocent person,
    but the upright show concern for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fool vents all his feelings,
    but the wise person keeps them to himself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a ruler is listening to lies,
    all of his officials tend to become wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor man and the oppressor have this in common:
    the Lord gave them both eyes with which to see.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a king faithfully administers justice to the poor,
    his throne will be established forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rod and rebuke bestow wisdom,
    but an undisciplined child brings shame to his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the wicked grow powerful, transgression increases,
    but the righteous will observe their downfall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Correct your son and he will comfort you;
    he will also delight your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without prophetic vision, people abandon restraint,
    but those who obey the Law are happy.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Do you see a man who speaks hastily?
    There is more hope for a fool than for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you pamper a servant from his childhood,
    later on he’ll become ungrateful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An angry man stirs up arguments,
    and a hot-tempered man causes many transgressions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person’s pride will bring about his downfall,
    but the humble in spirit will gain honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A thief’s accomplice hates himself;
    though testifying under oath, he reveals nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fearing any human being is a trap,
    but confiding in the Lord keeps anyone safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many seek a ruler’s favor,
    but justice for a man comes from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The unjust man is detestable to the righteous,
    and whoever lives blamelessly is detestable to the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A discourse by the faithful collector.
This is what this valiant man declared to the God with me,
    to the God with me, who then prevailed:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely I am beyond the senselessness of any man;
    I do not perceive things the way human beings do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I never acquired wisdom,
    but I know what the Holy One knows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has ascended to heaven,
    and then descended?
        Who has collected the wind in his hands?
Who has wrapped up waters in a garment?
    Who has established all the farthest points of the earth?
What is his name,
    and what is his son’s name?
        Surely you know!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everything God says is pure;
    he is a shield for those who take refuge in him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t add to his words,
    or he will rebuke you,
        and you will be shown to be a liar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God, I have asked you for two things—
    don’t refuse me before I die—
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep deception and lies far away from me,
    and give me neither poverty nor wealth.
Feed me with food that I need for today,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that I don’t become overfed and deny you by saying,
        “Who is the Lord?”
or so that I don’t become poor and steal,
    and then misuse the name of my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t lie about a servant to his master,
    or that servant will curse you and you will pay for it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some people curse their fathers
    and won’t bless their mothers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some people view themselves as pure,
    but haven’t been cleansed from their own filth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some people—what an arrogant look they have!—
    raise their eyebrows haughtily.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some people have swords for teeth
    and knives for fangs
to devour the afflicted from the earth
    and the needy from among mankind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The leech has two daughters:
    “Give” and “Give”.
Three things will never be satisfied;
    four will never say “Enough”—
speaker: Narrator

text:
The afterlife, the barren womb,
    earth that still demands water,
        and fire—they never say, “Enough”.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye that mocks a father
    and looks with a disobedient attitude at a mother—
the valley ravens will pluck it out;
    and vultures will eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Three things cause wonder for me;
    four are beyond my understanding:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way an eagle flies in the sky,
    the way of a serpent on a rock,
the way of a ship on the high seas,
    and the way of a man with a young woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what an immoral woman is like:
    she eats, wipes her mouth, then says
        “I’ve done nothing wrong.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Under three things the earth trembles,
    under four it cannot remain steady:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Under a slave when he becomes a king,
    a fool when he is overfed,
speaker: Narrator

text:
an unloved woman when she finds a husband,
    and a servant girl who inherits from her mistress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Four things on earth are small,
    but they are very, very wise:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ants aren’t a strong species,
    yet they prepare their food in the summer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rock badgers aren’t a strong species either,
    yet they build their dens in the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Locusts have no king,
    but they all swarm in ranks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Spiders can be caught by the hand,
    yet they’re found in kings’ palaces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Three things are stately in procession,
    four which are stately in their gait:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lion, mighty among the beasts,
    retreats before nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The strutting rooster, as well as the goat,
    and a king with his army.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you’ve foolishly exalted yourself
    or if you’ve plotted evil,
        put your hand over your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as whipping milk produces butter,
    and twisting the nose causes bleeding,
        so also stirring up anger produces contention.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of King Lemuel—
a pronouncement with which his mother encouraged him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No, my son!
    No, my son whom I conceived!
        No, my son to whom I gave birth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never devote all your energy to sex,
    or dedicate your life to destroying kings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not for kings, Lemuel—
    Not for kings to drink wine
        or for rulers to desire liquor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Otherwise, they may drink and forget what has been ordained,
    perverting justice for all the oppressed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give liquor to someone who is perishing,
    and wine to someone who is deeply depressed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let him drink, forget his poverty,
    and remember his troubles no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Speak for those who cannot speak;
    seek justice for all those on the verge of destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Speak up, judge righteously,
    and defend the rights of the afflicted and oppressed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can find a capable wife?
    Her value far exceeds the finest jewels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her husband has full confidence in her;
    as a result, he lacks nothing of value.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She will bring good to him—never evil—
    every day of her life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She seeks out wool and flax,
    working with eager hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is like a seagoing ship
    that brings her food from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She rises while it is still night,
    preparing meals for her family
        and providing for her women servants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She evaluates a field and purchases it;
    from the proceeds she plants a vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She clothes herself with fortitude,
    and fortifies her arms with strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is confident that her profits are sufficient.
    Her lamp does not go out at night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She works with her own hands on her clothes—
    her hands work the sewing spindle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She reaches out to the poor,
    opening her hands to those in need.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is unafraid of winter’s effect on her household,
    because all of them are warmly clothed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She creates her own bedding,
    using fine linen and violet cloth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her husband is well known;
    he sits among the leaders of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She designs and sells linen garments,
    supplying accessories to clothiers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strength and dignity are her garments;
    she smiles about the future.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She speaks wisely,
    teaching with gracious love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She looks discretely to the affairs of her household,
    and she is never lazy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her children stand up and encourage her,
    as does her husband, who praises her:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Many women have done wonderful things,” he says,
    “but you surpass all of them!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Charm is deceitful and beauty fades;
    but a woman who fears the Lord will be praised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Reward her for her work—
    let her actions result in public praise.
speaker: Narrator
